metadata.title: Introduction to NLP — Part 5B | Unsupervised topic model in Python | by Zolzaya Luvsandorj | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: Introduction to NLP — Part 5B | Unsupervised topic model in Python
metadata.description: This post will show you a simplified example of building a basic unsupervised topic model. We will use Latent Dirichlet Allocation (LDA here onwards) model. In short, LDA is a probabilistic model…

outgoing_paragraph_urls.anchor_text: Part 2: Difference between lemmatisation and stemming
Part 4: Supervised text classification model in Python
Part 5A: Unsupervised topic model in Python (sklearn)

all_paragraphs: This post will show you a simplified example of building a basic unsupervised topic model. We will use Latent Dirichlet Allocation (LDA here onwards) model. In short, LDA is a probabilistic model where each topic is considered as a mixture of words and each document is considered as a mixture of topics. Using LDA, we will attempt to identify the latent topics from corpus.

This post assumes that you have access to and are familiar with Python including installing packages, defining functions and other basic tasks. If you are new to Python, this is a good place to get started.
◻️ Make sure you have numpy, pandas, nltk, sklearn, gensim, matplotlib, seaborn, wordcloud and pyLDAvis installed.
◻️ Ensure you have downloaded ‘stopwords’ and ‘wordnet’ corpora from nltk
The script below can help you download these corpora. If you have already downloaded, running this will notify you that they are up-to-date:
Firstly, let’s prepare the environment by importing the required packages. We will also define a set of stop words to ignore:
To build an intuition, let’s create a small example with 4 documents. We can see that there are two topics: mangoes and board games. Let’s identify the clusters of topics with LDA:
As a first step, we will preprocess the data using a custom function:

If you are blurry on the details of the preprocessing we just did, this post explains the basic steps of preprocessing and this post (scroll to Section 2.2. Simple approach) briefly explains part-of-speech (POS) tagging and lemmatisation.

When doing a topic model, you may sometimes want to try using only one or several types of POS. For instance, if we think nouns are enough to identify topics, then we could adjust the script as below when creating documents:
Now the documents are preprocessed, let’s create a Gensim Dictionary object. It will map each unique word in the corpus to a numeric id as shown below:
We can see word: word id pairs in this output. For instance, word id = 5 represents ‘mango’. Using the dictionary, we can transform the preprocessed documents into numerical representation:

Here, we see (word id, word count) pairs for each unique word in the first document. In other words, the output is saying the first document contains:[1 x ‘board’, 1 x ‘game’, 1 x ‘play’, 1 x ‘yesterday’]

Okay, our data is in a state that models can understand, so let’s build a simple model. When building a model, we need to define the number of topics to the num_topics parameter. In this small example, we know there are two topics from reading the four short documents. However, often you wouldn’t know the number of topics and the suitable number of topics will be up to your judgement. We will also ask the model to pass through the corpus 20 times when training with passes argument.

The most important words are ‘play’, ‘game’ and ‘board’ (each with the same weight of 0.186) in topic 1 while the most important word in topic 2 is ‘mango’ (with a weight of 0.231). We will call topic 1 ‘board game’ and topic 2 ‘mango’. Now let’s find the dominant topic for each document.:
Great, dominant topics make sense! We can also see the probability for the dominant topic. Let’s see how it can assign a topic to a new document:
Yay! It predicted the topic correctly. Cool, having warmed up, we are ready to look at a more realistic example.
In this section, we will use three topics from Newsgroups dataset. This is to keep things manageable for this introductory post and easier to understand.
Let’s quickly check if there are uninformative examples. Looking at character length of documents will give an indication of too short documents.
Minimum is zero — these are empty documents. Let’s check out how under 20-character long documents look like:
These documents don’t tell us much, so let’s exclude them. However, if you believe they should be included or that the threshold should be altered, you can adjust so in the following script:
The shortest examples in the dataset now look more reasonable.

Usually, many consider partitioning dataset in unsupervised modelling has little value as there is no target to check against. However, I think it would be good to set aside a handful of unseen test documents to sense check the model later. With the following script, we will keep 5 records for this purpose.
Let’s transform the training documents into numerical representation.

To be more practical, let’s pretend we don’t know the number of topics and we will attempt to find the suitable number of topics with manual grid search. We will manually test a range of different topic numbers and assess them based on their coherence score. If you have an intuitive guess on the rough range of topics, one way to narrow down the options is to run manual grid search. However, take output of grid search as a guide only and check if the topics make sense.

The higher the c_v coherence score, the better. We can see that the model with 3 topics has the highest coherence score. Great, we know that we pulled 3 topics from Newsgroups data! Let’s run a LDA model with 3 topics now:

It appears that the first topic is about religion, the second topic is Mac/Apple and third topic is about sport— but we need more information. We will attempt to understand the topics better in Topic contextualisation section.
Let’s add the topic probabilities to each training document.
Now, let’s organise the probabilities. We will create a few new columns:

top1 column stores the most dominant topic for each record and prob1 columns stores the probability score for the most dominant topic. top2 and prob2 does the same for the second most dominant topic and so on. I find having the columns organised this way makes it easier to analyse the topics further. Let’s check for cases where top two topics have the same probability.

It’s hard to say these documents have dominant topic since the probabilities of all three topics are equal. It seems reasonable why the model have given equal probability since these documents are quite short. Luckily, we only have five cases. If we repeat the same for train['prob2']==train['prob3'], we will find the same 5 records. If you curious, check it out by adjusting the code above.
Now, let’s visualise the probability distribution for the most dominant topic. Ideally, we prefer if most probabilities are centered around higher value.
Great to see that majority of the values are close to 1. Let’s inspect the summary stats for the probability values:
Median probability for the most dominant topic is 0.9466. That’s awesome!
Now, let’s find the top words per topic to understand topics discovered:

From what we have seen so far, we can summarise the topics as follows:Topic 1: Religion related, particularly atheismTopic 2: Computer related, particularly Mac/AppleTopic 3: Sport related, particularly baseball
Let’s also look at word clouds per topic:
We can also use pyLDAvis package to visualise the topics interactively:

Of note, it’s important that you double check if the pyLDAvis topic numbers match with Gensim topic numbers by looking at the corresponding top word frequencies. In this particular example, you will notice that topics 2 & 3 are swapped in pyLDAvis. There’s an open issue regarding this confusing behaviour. In this post, we will use the topic numbers from Gensim.
With the topic exploration so far, we could name the topics as follows:
It’s hard to assess how well the model is doing from just looking at the head of the data. Let’s look at a few training examples closely and see how accurate the topic assignments are:

These three examples look good so far, but I won’t be surprised if there are some nonsensical assignments if you look at more examples. Now let’s assign topics to new cases and check the topic assignment:
Would you agree with these assignments? If we want to have a dataframe containing the documents, probabilities and the dominant topics, here’s one way to do so:

Voila, now you know how to run a basic unsupervised topic model! 🎓 While we ran only one iteration with 3 topics in this post, in reality you are likely to find yourself running multiple iterations with different components and other parameters to find a suitable model. So keep experimenting! ⭐️

Would you like to access more content like this? Medium members get unlimited access to any articles on Medium. If you become a member using my referral link, a portion of your membership fee will directly go to support me.

Thank you for taking the time to go through this post. I hope that you learned the basics of unsupervised topic modelling from reading it.
